Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Applying Redox Noninnocence: Tetrazine-Assisted Reduction of N2
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, funded by the NSF Chemical Synthesis Program, supports the research of Professor Kenneth Caulton of Indiana University to design and prepare new ligand structures that will wrap around low cost and sustainbable metal centers. The resultant complexes are used in the unusual catalytic conversion of poorly-reactive, thermodynamically-stable molecular nitrogen into value-added products. The new ligands contains imine functionalities, which makes them readily reducible so that they can temporarily store electrons to favor both the capture and reduction of nitrogen. Desirable nitrogen-containing products are formed using either organic trapping reagents or protons. The Caulton group employs low cost elements such as iron and vanadium in their catalysts making the materials more sustainable that those using precious metal catalysts. This project also systematizes and utilizes new ligand connectivities and electronic structures. Postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate researchers are actively involved in both the experimental and theoretical aspects of the project. The students receive excellent training in multiple characterizational techniques including electron paramagnetic resonance and x-ray photoelectron spectroscopies. Professor Caulton is active in the local chemistry community often lecturing on Nobel Prize-winning research to diverse audiences.

This research project focuses on the design and experimental investigation of a new tridentate, redox-active ligand, bis(tetrazinyl) pyridine (btzp), which acts in supporting metal-centered, multi-electron reduction processes such as the reduction of molecular nitrogen using the first row transition metals iron and vanadium. The imine-rich btzp ligand serves as electron reservoir, promoting redox reactions within a very narrow potential range. The availability of a number of nitrogen sites on the pincer ligand leads to novel reactivity including proton-coupled electron transfer or hydrogen atom transfer processes. The pincer nitrogens are directed outward and have a demonstrated ability to shuttle hydrogens, which converts the bound nitrogen to ammonia and amines; these products are commercially important chemicals. The conversion of molecular nitrogen into value-added products is of particular interest as it uses environmentally-friendly and low cost metals in the active catalyst.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has used original design principles of our own creation to assist the mere presence of a transition metal, as employed in heterogeneous catalysis, to enhanced capability in breaking robust, refractory chemical bonds under mild conditions, hence contributing to energy economical processes.  Our own choice of metals avoids expensive and strategically unreliable imported platinum metals, but then has to deal rationally with the differing electronic and bonding characteristics of our chosen “earth-abundant” metals, generally chromium, iron and cobalt.  This required creation of new places to store the electrons which accomplish the catalytically relevant transformations.  We have established that, in our targeted reductive cleavage of robust bonds involving the greenhouse gas carbon  dioxide, electrons are indeed stored not only at the metal component, but also at our designed ligand ancillary.  With chromium, we have characterized a type of aggregation using one of our “pincer” ligands which is unprecedented in that our designed construct collects four reducing equivalents in one molecule, as a result of the linking, bridging capability of a component of our ligand design.  This has led to the discovery of an unusual reaction which collects two CO2 molecules into a single product; while this is not the originally targeted oxalate, it nevertheless shows a new way of thinking about conversions of this greenhouse gas.  Using a different ligand construct, we have proven by a combination of multiple experimental and computational methods that electrons have been stored in the ligand.  While the particular molecules obtained lack sites for binding of substrate at chromium, the principles demonstrated are general, and are now being applied to other metals which will retain the ability to bind substrate; our synthetic principles are also general, and this leverages the importance of our work.  Moving to the metals iron and cobalt, we have carried out systematic study of the same ligand type used for chromium, and find a different type of aggregation, which organizes two metals together, leaving a site between the two for substrate binding and modification:  this is the essence of a two-metal advantage, which we have used to create a catalytic system which deoxygenates the greenhouse gas N2O by oxygen atom transfer to phosphines.  Our systematic comparison of iron and cobalt allows conclusion that the former is more reducing towards substrate, a conclusion which is opposite to what simple counting of the total number of metal valence electrons would predict, and we show the origin of this anomaly.  Finally we  have designed a third class of pincer ligand, which   combines the best of our own design, together with  the bulky phosphorus donor characteristic of work by others into an unsymmetrical pincer and which   reveals special advantages of such a hybrid:  richer characterization methods, retention of simple single metal character, and the ability  to  do hydrogen abstraction from ligand sp3 carbons, which opens us to study of general principles of radical metal  catalyst chemistry.  This enables us to collaborate in the spectroscopy of electron spins which, combined with computational analysis of orbitals, puts us in a position to exploit such unusual character for facile reductive process, especially those that require not only electrons but also protons; this is inherent to reduction of carbon dioxide to value-added multi-carbon compounds such as carboxylic acids, esters and alcohols, all of which represent capture and purposeful use of CO2.  Finally, in the final grant year, we have recognized that there are general similarities in reduction of nitrate and nitrogen oxyanions to that of CO2, and we moved, in the last 25% of this project, to using our same designed catalysts, to explore deoxygenation of the agricultural runoff and eutrophication pollutant nitrate.  This most recent work is now being prepared for publication, and presentation at conferences, and should attract greater attention of other homogenous catalysis researchers to this important theme related to sustainability.  Overall, we have done original thinking, followed by experimental and computational work to show new reactivity in a way which teaches the young students and postdoc creativity, problem solving and use of new methods (e.g. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy) to clarify understanding and discovery of new reactivity under energy-economical conditions; since this has been done not only for the original CO2 target, but also by our recognition of nitrate as a globally important target for  remediation, the project has been marked by exceptional growth and ambition of relevance to high impact pollution challenges.


Last Modified: 09/27/2017
Modified by: Kenneth G Caulton
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project has used original design principles of our own creation to assist the mere presence of a transition metal, as employed in heterogeneous catalysis, to enhanced capability in breaking robust, refractory chemical bonds under mild conditions, hence contributing to energy economical processes. Our own choice of metals avoids expensive and strategically unreliable imported platinum metals, but then has to deal rationally with the differing electronic and bonding characteristics of our chosen "earth-abundant" metals, generally chromium, iron and cobalt. This required creation of new places to store the electrons which accomplish the catalytically relevant transformations. We have established that, in our targeted reductive cleavage of robust bonds involving the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide, electrons are indeed stored not only at the metal component, but also at our designed ligand ancillary. With chromium, we have characterized a type of aggregation using one of our "pincer" ligands which is unprecedented in that our designed construct collects four reducing equivalents in one molecule, as a result of the linking, bridging capability of a component of our ligand design. This has led to the discovery of an unusual reaction which collects two CO2 molecules into a single product; while this is not the originally targeted oxalate, it nevertheless shows a new way of thinking about conversions of this greenhouse gas. Using a different ligand construct, we have proven by a combination of multiple experimental and computational methods that electrons have been stored in the ligand. While the particular molecules obtained lack sites for binding of substrate at chromium, the principles demonstrated are general, and are now being applied to other metals which will retain the ability to bind substrate; our synthetic principles are also general, and this leverages the importance of our work. Moving to the metals iron and cobalt, we have carried out systematic study of the same ligand type used for chromium, and find a different type of aggregation, which organizes two metals together, leaving a site between the two for substrate binding and modification: this is the essence of a two-metal advantage, which we have used to create a catalytic system which deoxygenates the greenhouse gas N2O by oxygen atom transfer to phosphines. Our systematic comparison of iron and cobalt allows conclusion that the former is more reducing towards substrate, a conclusion which is opposite to what simple counting of the total number of metal valence electrons would predict, and we show the origin of this anomaly. Finally we have designed a third class of pincer ligand, which combines the best of our own design, together with the bulky phosphorus donor characteristic of work by others into an unsymmetrical pincer and which reveals special advantages of such a hybrid: richer characterization methods, retention of simple single metal character, and the ability to do hydrogen abstraction from ligand sp3 carbons, which opens us to study of general principles of radical metal catalyst chemistry. This enables us to collaborate in the spectroscopy of electron spins which, combined with computational analysis of orbitals, puts us in a position to exploit such unusual character for facile reductive process, especially those that require not only electrons but also protons; this is inherent to reduction of carbon dioxide to value-added multi-carbon compounds such as carboxylic acids, esters and alcohols, all of which represent capture and purposeful use of CO2. Finally, in the final grant year, we have recognized that there are general similarities in reduction of nitrate and nitrogen oxyanions to that of CO2, and we moved, in the last 25% of this project, to using our same designed catalysts, to explore deoxygenation of the agricultural runoff and eutrophication pollutant nitrate. This most recent work is now being prepared for publication, and presentation at conferences, and should attract greater attention of other homogenous catalysis researchers to this important theme related to sustainability. Overall, we have done original thinking, followed by experimental and computational work to show new reactivity in a way which teaches the young students and postdoc creativity, problem solving and use of new methods (e.g. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy) to clarify understanding and discovery of new reactivity under energy-economical conditions; since this has been done not only for the original CO2 target, but also by our recognition of nitrate as a globally important target for remediation, the project has been marked by exceptional growth and ambition of relevance to high impact pollution challenges.
